question: Suppose you discovered a mutant yeast whose glycolytic pathway was shorter because of the presence of a new enzyme catalyzing the reaction <image 1> Would shortening the glycolytic pathway in this way benefit the cell?
description: The image depicts a biochemical reaction involving glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate (G3P) as the substrate. The reaction proceeds with the addition of water (H₂O), converting G3P into 3-phosphoglycerate. This transformation is coupled with the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD⁺) to its reduced form, NADH, along with the release of a proton (H⁺). The reaction is catalyzed by an enzyme, though the specific enzyme is not named in the image. The overall process shown is part of the glycolytic pathway, specifically the step where G3P is oxidized and phosphorylated to form 3-phosphoglycerate, generating NADH in the process.
